fiction.title: Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone
fiction.author: J.K. Rowling

metaphor.core: The magical process by which 'the wand chooses the wizard' in the Harry Potter universe serves as a metaphor for React props. Just as a wand's immutable properties (wood, core, length) define its nature and are determined by its maker (parent component) and cannot be changed by the wizard (child component), React props are read-only values passed from parent to child components, defining their configuration and behavior in a one-way data flow.

mapping.reactConcept: The parent React component, responsible for defining and passing props to its children.
A child React component, which receives props.
Props: read-only attributes or data passed from a parent component to configure a child component.

mapping.fictionElement: The wand 'choosing' the wizard (properties defining behavior)
mapping.reactConcept: How a child component's behavior and rendering are determined by the props it receives.

mapping.fictionElement: Ron Weasley trying to change his hand-me-down wand's core
mapping.reactConcept: The anti-pattern of attempting to mutate props directly within a child component, leading to errors or unexpected behavior.

mapping.fictionElement: The wand 'backfiring' when Ron tries to mutate it
mapping.reactConcept: The principle that props are immutable; attempts to change them in the child component are ineffective or lead to React warnings/errors.

mapping.fictionElement: Neville Longbottom getting a new wand that suits him
mapping.reactConcept: The correct pattern: if a child component needs a different configuration, its parent re-renders it with new props, rather than the child trying to change its own props.

mapping.fictionElement: The Great Hall filled with many unique wands
mapping.reactConcept: How many instances of the same component can be rendered with different sets of props to achieve varied appearances and behaviors.

metaphor.narrativeArc: The module follows Harry's wand selection at Ollivander's (introduction to props). It then depicts Ron's frustrated attempt to 'mutate' his hand-me-down wand's core, illustrating the immutability of props. This is contrasted with Neville's successful acquisition of a new wand with different properties (parent providing new props). A side-by-side comparison solidifies the lesson, culminating in the 'Great Hall of Wands' showing how diverse component instances are created through varied props.

problems: Attempting to directly modify props within a child component
Misunderstanding the unidirectional data flow in React
Confusion between component's own state and externally provided props.

chapters.title: The Wand Chooses the Wizard
chapters.focus: Introduces React props as immutable, read-only configurations passed from parent to child components.

chapters.title: The Stubborn Core
chapters.focus: Demonstrates the anti-pattern of attempting to mutate props directly within a child component and why it fails.

chapters.title: A New Wand for a New Task
chapters.focus: Explains the correct way to change a child's configuration: the parent component provides new props.

chapters.title: Two Wizards, Two Wands
chapters.focus: Provides a side-by-side comparison of the incorrect (mutating props) vs. correct (parent providing new props) approaches.

chapters.title: The Great Hall of Wands
chapters.focus: Illustrates the power of props for creating diverse instances of a reusable component, configuring each uniquely.
